question.body: Eponymous structures are named after a person, often the one who discovered it. Which of the following receptors with a historical eponymous name is not involved in proprioception?

response.feedback: Correct. This is found in the superficial region of dermis where it detects light touch, not body position or movement.
Incorrect. This is found in the deep region of dermis where it detects pressure and vibration
Incorrect. This is found in the dermis and associated with joints where it detects sustained pressure or changes in joint position, respectively.
Incorrect. This is found in the tendon between muscle and bone, providing sensory input when tendons are slowly stretched.

part.hint: One reason many of these structures now have a different name is because the eponymous name doesnâ€™t give any hints about its structure, location or function. However, if you use the table to review their location and know what structures are involved in detecting body position and movement, you should be able to decide which one does not fit.
